titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Karl Landsteiner papers, Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research Scientific Staff FA126

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-07 00:02:58 -0500.

did.unittitle: Karl Landsteiner papers, Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research Scientific Staff

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Karl Landsteiner was born in Vienna, Austria on June 14, 1868, and died on June 26, 1943 in New York. Karl Landsteiner began his medical career in 1891 with an M.D. from the University of Vienna. After graduating from medical school, Landsteiner worked as a research chemist.

Landsteiner was a physician and researcher in physiology, demonstrated the dependence of immunological phenomena on chemical structure. He made an immense and lasting contribution by his studies on blood. In 1930, Landsteiner received the Nobel Prize for his research in 1900 identifying and classifying the human blood groups A, B, AB, and O. He wrote many papers on immunology, bacteriology, and pathology, especially on the chemistry of antigens; human blood groups; experimental drug allergy; studies on syphilis; etiology of paroxysmal hemoglobinuria and the etiology of poliomyelitis. Karl Landsteiner was affiliated with the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research from 1922 until his death in 1943.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological and alphabetical order.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: In 1932, Dr. Merrill Chase came to the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research and began work with Karl Landsteiner. After Dr. Landsteiner's death, Dr. Chase carried on investigations and maintained custody of the Landsteiner laboratory notes and papers until he donated them to the Rockefeller University Archives over a period of five years starting in 1980. Some of the material was water-damaged in December 1982 while in Dr. Chase's care. Dr. Chase inserted his own notes and comments into the files. During 1968, Dr. Chase collected various publications and programs that honored the one hundredth anniversary of Karl Landsteiner's birth which have been included in the collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted pending permission from Rockefeller University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Types of records include: biographical material, correspondence, laboratory notes, manuscripts, reprints, and slides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subjects include Merrill W. Chase notes and Landsteiner estate correspondence.

did.unittitle: [Bibliography-memorial minute by Simon Flexner, staff, Austrian Commemorative stamp]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, English exercises, lab books, notes and tests, letters and transcripts from meetings, references, and scrapbooks. Lab notes and correspondence with Linus Pauling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes Edinburgh ms ("On Some (Recent) Aspects of Individual Blood Reactions"), "Molecular Structure and Intermolecular Forces" ms, Rh factor ms, "Specificity of Serological Reactions" ms, and "Systemic Anaphylaxis, Organ Anaphylaxis".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Includes drafts of ms "On some recent aspects of individual blood reaction"].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence and notes of Merrill Chase, Landsteiner first day cover and stamp, and 1968 NY Academy of Science Conference.
